intro: Berteroa incana var. trichocarpa, commonly known as the woolly morning glory, is a flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is characterized by its hairy, gray-green foliage and trumpet-shaped blue or purple flowers that bloom in the morning. The plant is typically found in arid or semi-arid environments, often growing along roadsides or in disturbed soils. Its leaves are palmately lobed, and the stems are covered in fine, white hairs. The species is part of the Convolvulaceae family, which includes other morning glories.
